text: What's a cover note?

options.A: A document issued before you receive your driving licence
options.B: A document issued before you receive your insurance certificate
options.C: A document issued before you receive your registration document
options.D: A document issued before you receive your MOT certificate

explanation: A document issued before you receive your insurance certificate. A cover note provides temporary proof of insurance until the certificate arrives.

text: You've just passed your first practical driving test. What will you have to do if you get six penalty points on your licence in the next two years?

options.A: Retake only your theory test
options.B: Reapply for your full licence immediately
options.C: Retake only your practical test
options.D: Retake your theory and practical tests

explanation: The details of your insurance. The certificate of insurance shows your coverage details, who's insured, and the period covered.

text:
For how long is a
Statutory Off-Road
Notification (SORN) valid?

options.A: Until the vehicle is used on the road
options.B: Until the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped
options.C: Until the vehicle is insured and MOT'd
options.D: Until the vehicle is repaired or modified

explanation: Your vehicle is over three years old. Most vehicles need an annual MOT test once they're three years old.

text:
What's a Statutory Off-
Road Notification (SORN)?

options.A: Information held by insurance companies to check a vehicle is insured
options.B: A notification to tell DVSA that a vehicle doesn't have a current MOT
options.C: Information kept by the police about the owner of a vehicle
options.D: A notification to tell DVLA that a vehicle isn't being used on the road

explanation: Driving without insurance. Driving without valid insurance is illegal and can result in penalty points, fines, and vehicle seizure.

text:
What's the maximum fine
for driving or riding without
insurance?

options.A: Unlimited

explanation: Before the vehicle is first used on the road. All vehicles must be taxed before being driven on public roads.

text:
Who's legally responsible
for ensuring that a vehicle
registration certificate (V5C)
is updated?

options.A: The registered vehicle keeper
options.B: The vehicle manufacturer
options.C: Your insurance company
options.D: The licensing authority

explanation: At least once a year. The MOT test must be done annually once the vehicle is over three years old.

text:
Your insurer will issue you
with an insurance certificate.
When must you produce this
document for inspection?

options.A: When making a SORN
options.B: When your vehicle is having an MOT test
options.C: When a police officer asks you for it
options.D: When buying or selling a vehicle

explanation: By notifying the DVLA. You must notify the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency of any change of address.

text:
When must your vehicle
have valid insurance cover?

options.A: Before you can tax the vehicle
options.B: Before you can make a SORN
options.C: Before you can sell the vehicle
options.D: Before you can scrap the vehicle

explanation: Anyone in charge of a vehicle on the road. The vehicle owner or keeper is responsible for ensuring it's taxed and insured.

text:
What do you need before
you can legally use a motor
vehicle on the road?

options.A: Proof of your identity
options.B: A vehicle handbook
options.C: An appropriate driving licence
options.D: Breakdown cover

explanation: Your insurance may be invalid. Modifications can affect insurance cover, so insurers must be notified.

text:
What must you have
when you apply to renew
your vehicle tax?

options.A: Valid insurance
options.B: The vehicle's chassis number
options.C: The handbook
options.D: A valid driving licence

explanation: The maximum amount your insurer will pay for damage. Policy excess is the amount you must pay towards any claim.

text:
A police officer asks to see your documents. You don't have them with you.
How many days do you have to produce them at a police station?

options.A: 21 days
options.B: 5 days
options.C: 7 days
options.D: 14 days

explanation: Comprehensive insurance. This provides the widest cover including damage to your own vehicle.

text:
When should you update
your vehicle registration
certificate?

options.A: When your vehicle needs an MOT
options.B: When you have a collision
options.C: When you move house
options.D: When you pass your driving test

explanation: Ensures your vehicle is roadworthy. The MOT test checks that vehicles meet minimum safety and environmental standards.

text:
What must you check
before you drive someone
else's vehicle?

options.A: That your own vehicle has insurance cover
options.B: That the insurance documents are in the vehicle
options.C: That the vehicle is insured for your use
options.D: That the vehicle owner has third-party insurance cover

explanation: The vehicle keeper. The registered keeper of the vehicle receives the V5C registration certificate.

text:
Your car needs to pass
an MOT test. What may be
invalidated if you drive the
car without a current MOT
certificate?

options.A: The vehicle insurance
options.B: The vehicle registration document
options.C: The vehicle tax
options.D: The vehicle service record

explanation: You're causing danger to other road users. MOT certificates can be revoked if the vehicle becomes dangerous.

text:
What legal requirement
must be met by a newly
qualified driver?

options.A: They must display green L plates
options.B: They must have valid motor insurance
options.C: They must be accompanied on their first motorway journey
options.D: They must have a new photograph taken for their full licence

explanation: It's valid for 12 months. A standard MOT certificate is valid for one year from the test date.

text:
What's covered by third-
party insurance?

options.A: Damage to other vehicles
options.B: Damage to your vehicle
options.C: Fire damage to your vehicle
options.D: Flood damage to your vehicle

explanation: Third party, fire and theft. This covers damage to other vehicles and theft or fire damage to yours.

text:
Who's responsible for
paying the vehicle tax?

options.A: The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)
options.B: The driver of the vehicle
options.C: The registered keeper of the vehicle
options.D: The car dealer

explanation: Tell your insurance company. Insurance must be notified of any accident, even if you don't claim.

text:
What information is
found on a vehicle
registration document?

options.A: The date of the MOT
options.B: The service history details
options.C: The type of insurance cover
options.D: The registered keeper

explanation: Your vehicle may be seized by the police. Driving without insurance is a serious offense leading to vehicle seizure.

text:
When must you contact
the Driver and Vehicle
Licensing Agency (DVLA)?

options.A: When you get a parking ticket
options.B: When you change your vehicle
options.C: When you use your vehicle for work
options.D: When your vehicle's insurance is due

explanation: The vehicle registration document (V5C). This document contains details about the vehicle and registered keeper.

text:
What circumstances
require you to notify the
Driver and Vehicle Licensing
Agency (DVLA)?

options.A: When your health affects your driving
options.B: When you have to work abroad
options.C: When you lend your vehicle to someone
options.D: When your vehicle needs an MOT certificate

explanation: Whether the exhaust emissions are acceptable. MOT tests include checking emissions meet environmental standards.

text:
When could the cost of
your insurance be reduced?

options.A: When you're under 25 years old
options.B: When you don't wear glasses
options.C: When you pass the driving test first time
options.D: When you complete the Pass Plus scheme

explanation: You must tell your insurance company. Insurers must be informed of penalty points as they affect risk assessment.

text:
In order to supervise a learner driver you need to 
have held a full driving 
licence for the same 
category of vehicle, for at 
least three years. What other requirement must you meet?

options.A: To hold an advanced driving certificate
options.B: To have a car with dual controls
options.C: To be at least 21 years old
options.D: To be an approved driving instructor

explanation: Up to six months before it runs out. You can renew MOT up to a month early and keep the same renewal date.

text:
Your car requires an
MOT certificate. When is it
legal to drive it without an
MOT certificate?

options.A: Up to seven days after the old certificate has run out
options.B: When driving to an appointment at an MOT centre
options.C: When driving the car with the owner’s permission
options.D: When driving to an MOT centre to arrange an appointment

explanation: Notify the DVLA immediately. Medical conditions that affect driving must be reported to DVLA.

text:
What does it mean if
your insurance policy has
an excess of £500?

options.A: The insurance company will pay the first £500 of any claim
options.B: You'll be paid £500 if you don't claim within one year
options.C: Your vehicle is insured for a value of £500 if it's stolen
options.D: You'll have to pay the first£500 of the cost of any claim

explanation: It's illegal to drive without insurance. Insurance is a legal requirement for all vehicles used on public roads.
